      • getMimeHeaderValue

        public static String getMimeHeaderValue(org.forgerock.services.context.Context serverContext,
                                        String headerName)
        Returns the value of the named header field from the request, decoding it if it is mime-encoded. If the header is not mime-encoded then it is returned as-is. If no such header is present, then null is returned. If there are multiple values for the header, then the first value is returned.
        Parameters:
        serverContext - the context of the request. Must contain a HttpContext.
        headerName - the name of the header to get.
        Returns:
        the decoded header value, or null if no such header exists in the request.
        See Also:
        RFC 2047: MIME Part 3: Message Header Extensions for Non-ASCII Text

      • getMimeHeaderValue

        public static String getMimeHeaderValue(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request,
                                        String headerName)
        Returns the value of the named header field from the request, decoding it if it is mime-encoded. If the header is not mime-encoded then it is returned as-is. If no such header is present, then null is returned.If there are multiple values for the header, then the first value is returned.
        Parameters:
        request - HTTPServletRequest
        headerName - the name of the header to get.
        Returns:
        the decoded header value, or null if no such header exists in the request.
        See Also:
        RFC 2047: MIME Part 3: Message Header Extensions for Non-ASCII Text

      • isContractConformantUserProvidedIdCreate

        public static boolean isContractConformantUserProvidedIdCreate(org.forgerock.services.context.Context serverContext,
                                                               org.forgerock.json.resource.CreateRequest createRequest)
        Check to see if the create request should be treated as a client-provided ID create request in a CREST contract-conformant way.

        When handling CREST create requests with protocol 1.0, OpenAM returned a 'Conflict' error response regardless of whether the resource's ID was client-specified or server-generated. In the case of the former, a create request was supposed to always have an if-none-match header (note: OpenAM functional tests generally did not conform to this either). This being the case, the correct response would be precondition-failed, rather than conflict.

        As OpenAM will have to honour its incorrect behaviour for pre-OpenAM 14 clients, this method can be used to distinguish a request that should be handled in a conformant way rather than one that should be handled in the legacy way. New resource providers should not use this method, but should correctly handle all client-provided ID request (where CreateRequest.getNewResourceId() return a non-null value) properly.

        Parameters:
        serverContext - The context for the request.
        createRequest - The request object.
        Returns:
        How the request should be handled.
